subject: Re: Using SCIM to type Quikscript
msgSnippet: Yes, I m very interested. I recently switched from Windows to Linux (Ubuntu 8.40) and miss the Shavian and Quickscript keyboard layouts I made. I had interest
messageBody:
Yes, I'm very interested. I recently switched from Windows to Linux
(Ubuntu 8.40) and miss the Shavian and Quickscript keyboard layouts I
made. I had interest in making an SCIM table for Shavian (Linux
actually implements Unicode!) but my skills in the area are altogether
lacking.

If you could post the table, I would gladly test it. Which layout does
it use?

Thanks a lot.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Anthony Hagan" <anthonydh@...>

> prOgres...
>
> And for those who can't see Jerome either:
>
> Gosh it's been quiet here lately.
>
> Since the keyboard layout poll, I've set up some SCIM tables so that one
> can type using Peter Guiness' layout, and get QS text in either the
> Unicode Private Use Area (as used by Paul Tremblay's ThothUni font) or
> in the Jerome or King Plus fonts. If anyone is at all interested, I'll
> put the tables up in the files area.
>
> SCIM (Smart Common/Chinese Input Method) is a Unix/Linux/BSD tool for
> typing in multiple scripts, so sorry this wouldn't be any use to Windows
> and Mac users. That's why I'll only post if there's some interest.
>
> As the Jerome version shows, the SCIM table includes a preliminary
> attempt at using senior forms. Like most things in QS, this is a work
> in progress...
>
